title: Chinese Embassy donates school supplies to first graders in Armenia to improve quality of school on August 27, 2021
description: On August 27, 2021, the Chinese Ambassador to Armenia, Fan Yong, donated Chinese school supplies to first-grade students in the Russian-dominated Lermontovo village and Fioletovo village.   He also included a letter encouraging students to study hard.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
Chinese Embassy donates school supplies to first graders in Armenia to improve quality of school on August 27, 2021

# Description
On August 27, 2021, the Chinese Ambassador to Armenia, Fan Yong, donated Chinese school supplies to first-grade students in the Russian-dominated Lermontovo village and Fioletovo village.   He also included a letter encouraging students to study hard.
justification: Project focuses on educational support without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Donation of school supplies to first-grade students, educational focus

title: Chinese Government donates 100,000 Sinovac Covid-19 vaccine doses worth $1.8 million in May 2021
description: On April 28, 2021, Minister of Health of Armenia, Anahit Avanesyan, announced that the Chinese Government would donate 100,000 vaccines, enough to vaccinate 50,000 people. Then, on May 2, 2021, the donation of 100,000 Sinovac COVID-19 vaccines arrived at Yerevan International Airport in the capital of Armenia. China’s Ambassador to Armenia Fan Yong, Armenian Deputy Foreign Minister Adonci, and representatives of the Ministry of Health went to the airport to greet them. On May 7, 2021, the handover ceremony for this donation was held at the Ministry of Health of Armenia. Ambassador Fan Yong and the Minister of Health Avanezian signed the handover certificate on behalf of their respective governments.
staff_comments: 1. According to the UNICEF COVID-19 Vaccine Market Dashboard, the price of a single Sinovac COVID-19 vaccine dose is $18 (https://www.oecd.org/officialdocuments/publicdisplaydocumentpdf/?cote=DCD/DAC/STAT(2022)33&docLanguage=En). As such, AidData has estimated the monetary value of the May 2021 donation as $1.8 million.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Government donates 100,000 Sinovac Covid-19 vaccine doses worth $1.8 million in May 2021

# Description
On April 28, 2021, Minister of Health of Armenia, Anahit Avanesyan, announced that the Chinese Government would donate 100,000 vaccines, enough to vaccinate 50,000 people. Then, on May 2, 2021, the donation of 100,000 Sinovac COVID-19 vaccines arrived at Yerevan International Airport in the capital of Armenia. China’s Ambassador to Armenia Fan Yong, Armenian Deputy Foreign Minister Adonci, and representatives of the Ministry of Health went to the airport to greet them. On May 7, 2021, the handover ceremony for this donation was held at the Ministry of Health of Armenia. Ambassador Fan Yong and the Minister of Health Avanezian signed the handover certificate on behalf of their respective governments.
justification: Project is a vaccine donation with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of 100,000 Sinovac COVID-19 vaccines, healthcare sector project

title: China builds a new broadcasting pavilion of the Public Television of Armenia through an E.T.C.A signed in November 2021
description: On November 15, 2021, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of Armenia signed an agreement Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement between the Government of the Republic of Armenia and the Government of the People's Republic of China. The agreement was signed by Armenia’s Deputy Foreign Minister Armen Ghevondyan, and the Ambassador of the People's Republic of China to the Republic of Armenia, Fan Yong.  China commits to build a new broadcasting pavilion for Armenia under this agreement.
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
China builds a new broadcasting pavilion of the Public Television of Armenia through an E.T.C.A signed in November 2021

# Description
On November 15, 2021, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of Armenia signed an agreement Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement between the Government of the Republic of Armenia and the Government of the People's Republic of China. The agreement was signed by Armenia’s Deputy Foreign Minister Armen Ghevondyan, and the Ambassador of the People's Republic of China to the Republic of Armenia, Fan Yong.  China commits to build a new broadcasting pavilion for Armenia under this agreement.

evidence: Broadcasting pavilion construction, no energy or environmental components mentioned

title: China establishes Confucius Auditorium at Yerevan’s Russian-Aremenian University in October 2021
description: On October 28, 2021, The Yerevan’s Russian-Aremenian University opened a Confucius Auditorium. Ambassador of China to Armenia Fan Yong spoke at the inauguration. The auditorium is a result of Dalian University of Foreign Languages and RAU. The auditorium gives the chance for students to better get to know the culture and language of China and to deepen economic skills and mutual interest between China and Armenia.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title

# Description
On October 28, 2021, The Yerevan’s Russian-Aremenian University opened a Confucius Auditorium. Ambassador of China to Armenia Fan Yong spoke at the inauguration. The auditorium is a result of Dalian University of Foreign Languages and RAU. The auditorium gives the chance for students to better get to know the culture and language of China and to deepen economic skills and mutual interest between China and Armenia.
justification: Project focuses on cultural and educational exchange without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Establishment of Confucius Auditorium for cultural and language education, deepening mutual interest between China and Armenia

title: PRC Poverty Reduction and Regional Cooperation Fund provides $800,000 USD for ADB Green and Resilient Rural Recovery project
description: Approved on December 16, 2021, the Asian Development Bank's project "Green and Resilient Rural Recovery through Agri-food System Transformation in Asia Pacific Region" was partially financed by the Chinese Poverty Reduction and Regional Cooperation Fund, which provided $800,000 USD. Other financiers were the Technical Assistance Special Fund with $1.5  million USD, the Regional Cooperation and Integration Fund with $500,000 USD, the Climate Change Fund with $750,000, and the Strategic Climate Fund $550,000 USD.   The project's goals are to assess the impact of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) on the region's food and nutrition security and rural livelihood and help developing member countries (DMCs) of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) reshape their visions and investments for a greener and resilient recovery of agri-food value chains and rural economies from disruptions caused by COVID-19. It intends to address the ways in which COVID-19 has exacerbated rural poverty and food and nutrition insecurity, particularly among women and vulnerable groups.
combined_text:
# Sector
AGRICULTURE, FORESTRY, FISHING

# Title
PRC Poverty Reduction and Regional Cooperation Fund provides $800,000 USD for ADB Green and Resilient Rural Recovery project

# Description
Approved on December 16, 2021, the Asian Development Bank's project "Green and Resilient Rural Recovery through Agri-food System Transformation in Asia Pacific Region" was partially financed by the Chinese Poverty Reduction and Regional Cooperation Fund, which provided $800,000 USD. Other financiers were the Technical Assistance Special Fund with $1.5  million USD, the Regional Cooperation and Integration Fund with $500,000 USD, the Climate Change Fund with $750,000, and the Strategic Climate Fund $550,000 USD.   The project's goals are to assess the impact of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) on the region's food and nutrition security and rural livelihood and help developing member countries (DMCs) of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) reshape their visions and investments for a greener and resilient recovery of agri-food value chains and rural economies from disruptions caused by COVID-19. It intends to address the ways in which COVID-19 has exacerbated rural poverty and food and nutrition insecurity, particularly among women and vulnerable groups.
justification: Project focuses on rural recovery, poverty reduction, and food security without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Focus on COVID-19 recovery, rural livelihoods, and food security; no specific energy or environmental components mentioned

title: Lancang-Mekong Cooperation and China Civil Aviation Administration offer Aviation Training course for Cambodia, Laos, and Vietnam
description: On October 11th, the opening ceremony of the Lancang-Mekong Cooperation (LMC) Aviation Training Course began. This course will help train 52 professionals from Cambodia, Laos and Vietnam in civil aviation specialties, including air traffic control, flight dispatch and aircraft maintenance.  The training course, which is offered by Civil Aviation Flight University of China (CAFUC), will last for two months, from mid-October to mid-December. It was taught online because of the COVID-19 pandemic.   A total of 56 teachers taught participants civil aviation theories and practices in English. The course will have a total of 1186 class hours (including 484 class hours for theoretical courses and 702 class hours for practical training courses). Subjects taught include "Radar control training for civil aviation controllers in countries along the Lancang and Mekong Rivers", "competence-based training for flight dispatchers in Lancang-Mekong countries" and "cultivation of civil aircraft maintenance professionals in countries along the Lancang-Mekong River." The closing ceremony of the course was held on December 20th, 2021, with all 52 students successfully completing the course.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
Lancang-Mekong Cooperation and China Civil Aviation Administration offer Aviation Training course for Cambodia, Laos, and Vietnam

# Description
On October 11th, the opening ceremony of the Lancang-Mekong Cooperation (LMC) Aviation Training Course began. This course will help train 52 professionals from Cambodia, Laos and Vietnam in civil aviation specialties, including air traffic control, flight dispatch and aircraft maintenance.  The training course, which is offered by Civil Aviation Flight University of China (CAFUC), will last for two months, from mid-October to mid-December. It was taught online because of the COVID-19 pandemic.   A total of 56 teachers taught participants civil aviation theories and practices in English. The course will have a total of 1186 class hours (including 484 class hours for theoretical courses and 702 class hours for practical training courses). Subjects taught include "Radar control training for civil aviation controllers in countries along the Lancang and Mekong Rivers", "competence-based training for flight dispatchers in Lancang-Mekong countries" and "cultivation of civil aircraft maintenance professionals in countries along the Lancang-Mekong River." The closing ceremony of the course was held on December 20th, 2021, with all 52 students successfully completing the course.
justification: Project is focused on education and training in civil aviation specialties, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Aviation training course for professionals, focus on civil aviation theories and practices, no energy-related components mentioned

title: Chinese Government donates 150,000 Covid-19 vaccine doses worth $2.7 million in April 2021
description: On April 24, 2021, the Chinese Government delivered 150,000 donated doses of Sinovac Covid-19 vaccines to the Government of Azerbaijan. A handover ceremony was held for this donation on April 27, 2021 at the Ministry of Health in Azerbaijan. China’s Ambassador to Azerbaijan, Guo Min, the Deputy Minister of Health of Azerbaijan, the Director of the International Cooperation Bureau of the Ministry of Health, officials from the National Compulsory Medical Insurance Administration, and members of the Local Medical Institutions Supervision Bureau attended the ceremony. Ambassador Guo Min and the Deputy Minister of Health of Azerbaijan jointly signed the handover certificate at the ceremony. The donation was announced by the Chinese Ambassador to Azerbaijan on April 1, 2021
staff_comments: 1. According to the UNICEF COVID-19 Vaccine Market Dashboard, the price of a single Sinovac COVID-19 vaccine dose is $18 (https://www.oecd.org/officialdocuments/publicdisplaydocumentpdf/?cote=DCD/DAC/STAT(2022)33&docLanguage=En). As such, AidData has estimated the monetary value of the April 2021 donation as $2.7 million.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Government donates 150,000 Covid-19 vaccine doses worth $2.7 million in April 2021

# Description
On April 24, 2021, the Chinese Government delivered 150,000 donated doses of Sinovac Covid-19 vaccines to the Government of Azerbaijan. A handover ceremony was held for this donation on April 27, 2021 at the Ministry of Health in Azerbaijan. China’s Ambassador to Azerbaijan, Guo Min, the Deputy Minister of Health of Azerbaijan, the Director of the International Cooperation Bureau of the Ministry of Health, officials from the National Compulsory Medical Insurance Administration, and members of the Local Medical Institutions Supervision Bureau attended the ceremony. Ambassador Guo Min and the Deputy Minister of Health of Azerbaijan jointly signed the handover certificate at the ceremony. The donation was announced by the Chinese Ambassador to Azerbaijan on April 1, 2021
justification: Project is a vaccine donation with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: 150,000 donated doses of Sinovac Covid-19 vaccines, healthcare sector project

title: Bank of China contributes to $255 million syndicated loan to SOCAR for refinancing and general corporate purposes
description: On September 17, 2021, the State Oil Company of Azerbaijan Republic (SOCAR) secured a $255 million syndicated loan agreement with a 1-year maturity and an unknown interest rate. Participants in the loan syndicate include Arab Petroleum Investments Corporation, Commercial Bank of Dubai, Bank of China, ING Group, CA Indosuez, Rabobank, Raiffeisen Banking Group, Mizuho Financial Group, First Abu Dhabi Bank, National Bank of Fujairah, UBAF, and Arab Banking Corporation. Each member of the syndicate reportedly contributed $19.62 million. The proceeds of the loan were to be use by the borrower to refinance its existing $210 million revolver, as well as for general corporate purposes.
combined_text:
# Sector
INDUSTRY, MINING, CONSTRUCTION

# Title
Bank of China contributes to $255 million syndicated loan to SOCAR for refinancing and general corporate purposes

# Description
On September 17, 2021, the State Oil Company of Azerbaijan Republic (SOCAR) secured a $255 million syndicated loan agreement with a 1-year maturity and an unknown interest rate. Participants in the loan syndicate include Arab Petroleum Investments Corporation, Commercial Bank of Dubai, Bank of China, ING Group, CA Indosuez, Rabobank, Raiffeisen Banking Group, Mizuho Financial Group, First Abu Dhabi Bank, National Bank of Fujairah, UBAF, and Arab Banking Corporation. Each member of the syndicate reportedly contributed $19.62 million. The proceeds of the loan were to be use by the borrower to refinance its existing $210 million revolver, as well as for general corporate purposes.
justification: The loan is for general corporate purposes and refinancing, with no specific environmental or energy transition-related purpose stated
evidence: Syndicated loan for refinancing and general corporate purposes, no specific project details provided

title: Bank of China contributes $66 million to a $400 million syndicated loan for BTC Pipeline Refinancing Project (Linked to Project ID#65866, #65867, and #96454)
description: In 2003, the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) issued a $125 million loan and a syndicate of commercial banks issued a $125 million loan to Baku-Tbilisi-Ceyhan Pipeline Company (BTC) — a special purpose vehicle — for the Baku-Tbilisi-Ceyhan Pipeline Construction Project. BTC’s shareholders are BP (30,1%), SOCAR (25,00%), Unocal (8,90%), Statoil (8,71%), TPAO (6,53%), Eni (5,00%), Total (5,00%), Itochu (3,40%), INPEX (2,50%), ConocoPhillips (2,50%) and Amerada Hess (2,36%). This project involved the construction of a 1,768 km oil pipeline from the Azeri-Chirag-Guneshli oil field in the Caspian Sea to the Ceylon Terminal located on the Turkish coast of the Mediterranean Sea. This pipeline passes through Azerbaijan, Georgia, and Turkey. From the Ceyhan Terminal, the oil is distributed to international markets.  The Baku-Tbilisi-Ceyhan Pipeline Company was established in London on August 1, 2002. A ceremony launching construction of the pipeline was held on September 18, 2002. Construction began in April 2003 and was completed in 2005. The Azerbaijan section was constructed by Consolidated Contractors International of Greece, and Georgia's section was constructed by a joint venture of France's Spie Capag and UK Petrofac International. The Turkish section was constructed by BOTAŞ Petroleum Pipeline Corporation. Bechtel was the main contractor for engineering, procurement, and construction. On May 25, 2005, the pipeline was inaugurated at the Sangachal Terminal by President Ilham Aliyev of the Azerbaijan Republic, President Mikhail Saakashvili of Georgia, and President Ahmet Sezer of Turkey, joined by President Nursultan Nazarbayev of Kazakhstan and United States Secretary of Energy Samuel Bodman. The inauguration of the Georgian section was hosted by President Mikheil Saakashvili at the pumping station near Gardabani on October 12, 2005. The inauguration ceremony at the Ceyhan terminal was held on July 13, 2006.  The pipeline was gradually filled with 10 million barrels of oil flowing from Baku and reaching Ceyhan on May 28, 2006. The first oil was loaded at the Ceyhan Marine Terminal (Haydar Aliyev Terminal) onto a tanker named British Hawthorn. The tanker sailed on June 4, 2006, with about 600,000 barrels (95,000 m3) of crude oil. As of June 30, 2014, 15.0 million tons of oil and condensate produced in Azerbaijan were transported through the BTC Pipeline, representing 69.8% of the total oil and condensate produced in Azerbaijan, and, as of December 2013, 29.8 million tons of oil and condensate produced in Azerbaijan, were transported through the BTC Pipeline, representing 68.5% of the total oil and condensate produced in Azerbaijan.  As of June 30, 2014, the BTC Pipeline had a throughput capacity of 1.2 mbd and 60 million tonnes per annum. Then, on November 17, 2015, a syndicated of banks — Including Bank of China (BoC) and the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) — issued a $1.63 billion syndicated loan facility to the Baku-Tbilisi-Ceyhan (BTC) Pipeline Company (BTC) for ‘capital and business operations.’ BoC contributed $260.26 million (captured in Project ID#65866), while ICBC contributed $173.51 million (captured in Project ID#65867). Other members of the loan syndicate included MUFG, SMBC, HSBC, Société Générale, Citi and BNP Paribas Fortis. The five-year amortizing term loan is non-recourse to BTC’s shareholders and it was scheduled to mature in December 2020. The proceeds of the loan were to be used by the borrower for ‘capital and business operations.’ Then, on October 20, 2021, BTC signed a $400.17 million syndicated loan agreement with six Chinese and non-Chinese banks (including MUFG, Société Générale, Citibank, Credit Agricole Group, Bank of China and ICBC). This loan carries a 4-year maturity and an unknown interest rate. Bank of China and ICBC each contributed $66.67 million to the syndicate, captured in Project ID#96452 and #96454 respectively. The proceeds of the loan were to be used by the borrower to refinance debts previously incurred to build the Baku-Tbilisi-Ceyhan Pipeline.
combined_text:
# Sector
INDUSTRY, MINING, CONSTRUCTION

# Title
Bank of China contributes $66 million to a $400 million syndicated loan for BTC Pipeline Refinancing Project (Linked to Project ID#65866, #65867, and #96454)

# Description
In 2003, the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) issued a $125 million loan and a syndicate of commercial banks issued a $125 million loan to Baku-Tbilisi-Ceyhan Pipeline Company (BTC) — a special purpose vehicle — for the Baku-Tbilisi-Ceyhan Pipeline Construction Project. BTC’s shareholders are BP (30,1%), SOCAR (25,00%), Unocal (8,90%), Statoil (8,71%), TPAO (6,53%), Eni (5,00%), Total (5,00%), Itochu (3,40%), INPEX (2,50%), ConocoPhillips (2,50%) and Amerada Hess (2,36%). This project involved the construction of a 1,768 km oil pipeline from the Azeri-Chirag-Guneshli oil field in the Caspian Sea to the Ceylon Terminal located on the Turkish coast of the Mediterranean Sea. This pipeline passes through Azerbaijan, Georgia, and Turkey. From the Ceyhan Terminal, the oil is distributed to international markets.  The Baku-Tbilisi-Ceyhan Pipeline Company was established in London on August 1, 2002. A ceremony launching construction of the pipeline was held on September 18, 2002. Construction began in April 2003 and was completed in 2005. The Azerbaijan section was constructed by Consolidated Contractors International of Greece, and Georgia's section was constructed by a joint venture of France's Spie Capag and UK Petrofac International. The Turkish section was constructed by BOTAŞ Petroleum Pipeline Corporation. Bechtel was the main contractor for engineering, procurement, and construction. On May 25, 2005, the pipeline was inaugurated at the Sangachal Terminal by President Ilham Aliyev of the Azerbaijan Republic, President Mikhail Saakashvili of Georgia, and President Ahmet Sezer of Turkey, joined by President Nursultan Nazarbayev of Kazakhstan and United States Secretary of Energy Samuel Bodman. The inauguration of the Georgian section was hosted by President Mikheil Saakashvili at the pumping station near Gardabani on October 12, 2005. The inauguration ceremony at the Ceyhan terminal was held on July 13, 2006.  The pipeline was gradually filled with 10 million barrels of oil flowing from Baku and reaching Ceyhan on May 28, 2006. The first oil was loaded at the Ceyhan Marine Terminal (Haydar Aliyev Terminal) onto a tanker named British Hawthorn. The tanker sailed on June 4, 2006, with about 600,000 barrels (95,000 m3) of crude oil. As of June 30, 2014, 15.0 million tons of oil and condensate produced in Azerbaijan were transported through the BTC Pipeline, representing 69.8% of the total oil and condensate produced in Azerbaijan, and, as of December 2013, 29.8 million tons of oil and condensate produced in Azerbaijan, were transported through the BTC Pipeline, representing 68.5% of the total oil and condensate produced in Azerbaijan.  As of June 30, 2014, the BTC Pipeline had a throughput capacity of 1.2 mbd and 60 million tonnes per annum. Then, on November 17, 2015, a syndicated of banks — Including Bank of China (BoC) and the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) — issued a $1.63 billion syndicated loan facility to the Baku-Tbilisi-Ceyhan (BTC) Pipeline Company (BTC) for ‘capital and business operations.’ BoC contributed $260.26 million (captured in Project ID#65866), while ICBC contributed $173.51 million (captured in Project ID#65867). Other members of the loan syndicate included MUFG, SMBC, HSBC, Société Générale, Citi and BNP Paribas Fortis. The five-year amortizing term loan is non-recourse to BTC’s shareholders and it was scheduled to mature in December 2020. The proceeds of the loan were to be used by the borrower for ‘capital and business operations.’ Then, on October 20, 2021, BTC signed a $400.17 million syndicated loan agreement with six Chinese and non-Chinese banks (including MUFG, Société Générale, Citibank, Credit Agricole Group, Bank of China and ICBC). This loan carries a 4-year maturity and an unknown interest rate. Bank of China and ICBC each contributed $66.67 million to the syndicate, captured in Project ID#96452 and #96454 respectively. The proceeds of the loan were to be used by the borrower to refinance debts previously incurred to build the Baku-Tbilisi-Ceyhan Pipeline.
justification: Project involves refinancing of an oil pipeline, directly supporting fossil fuel infrastructure
evidence: Baku-Tbilisi-Ceyhan Pipeline transports oil, refinancing supports continued fossil fuel operations
